name: Advanced History & Shortcuts
description: Learn advanced command history usage and keyboard shortcuts

flashcards.question: How do you count the number of characters in /etc/group and /etc/hosts?
flashcards.answer: Use wc -c followed by the file names.

flashcards.question: What is the command to display the first 3 lines of two files using backslashes to continue the command?
flashcards.answer: Use head -n 3 followed by backslashes and file names.
flashcards.example:
$ head -n 3 \
> /usr/share/dict/words \
> /usr/share/dict/linux.words
==> /usr/share/dict/words <==
A
a
aa

==> /usr/share/dict/linux.words <==
4th
Abbas
abbey

flashcards.question: What is the function of the exclamation point ! character in the command line?
flashcards.answer: It is used to recall and execute commands from your history.
flashcards.example:
!! repeats the last command.
!n executes the command with history number n.
!string executes the last command starting with string.

flashcards.question: How do you recall and execute the 20th command from the history list?
What does the !number command do?
flashcards.answer: It executes the command corresponding to that number in the history list.

flashcards.question: What does the !string command do?
flashcards.answer: It executes the most recent command that begins with the specified string.
flashcards.example:
$ !ls
... (executes the most recent command starting with 'ls')

flashcards.question: How do you clear from the cursor to the beginning of the command line using a shortcut?
flashcards.example: Place the cursor where you want to start clearing, then press Ctrl+U.

flashcards.question: What shortcut searches the history list of commands for a pattern?
flashcards.example: Press Ctrl+R and type the search pattern.

flashcards.question: How do you jump to the beginning of the previous word on the command line?
flashcards.answer: Press Alt+B or Esc then B
flashcards.example: Use this to navigate back one word at a time while editing a command.

flashcards.question: What does Ctrl+A do in the command line?
flashcards.answer: Jumps to the beginning of the command line.
flashcards.example: Press Ctrl+A to move the cursor to the start of the line.
